.W: Family, twin, and adoption studies have suggested an important role for hereditary factors in the etiology and pathogenesis of several psychiatric disorders. .W: Splitting is a concept that is used in a variety of ways to describe several different phenomena commonly seen in hospital treatment. A clearer conceptual understanding of splitting in the hospital allows for its differentiation from common variants of splitting and for the development of strategies to manage splitting.

.T: Hormones and breast cancer.
.W: Patients with successfully managed breast cancer have generally been denied subsequent exposure to increased levels of estrogen (endogenous or exogenous) based on the belief that exacerbation of the cancer would occur. .T: Considerations for anesthetic management during veno-venous bypass in adult hepatic transplantation.
.W: Intraoperative data from 42 adult orthotopic hepatic transplant recipients were analyzed retrospectively to assess the hemodynamic, coagulation, and thermal effects of heparinless veno-venous bypass using a constrained vortex pump. Abrupt decreases in cardiac output and pump flow occurred with termination of the portal limb of bypass, which is required to allow completion of the portal vein anastomosis. Patient core temperature decreased three times more rapidly (0.9 degrees C/hr) during bypass than at any other time during the procedure.

The selective distal splenorenal shunt is the most widely used portosystemic shunt today, particularly in nonalcoholic cirrhotic patients. Two thinking models are employed by managers--a rational one (hard box) and an intuitive one (soft bubble). These thinking models, or cognitive styles, can also be defined as left and right brain skills.
